title: Brexit: How Boris Johnson came back from Brussels with a deal 'worse than May's'

Boris Johnson's deal has been monstered by critics - who said it was worse than Theresa May's.

Labour's Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer issued stark warnings about the agreement.

He wrote on Twitter : "Labour's concerns with Theresa May's deal were not principally about the backstop. They were about the Political Declaration and our future relationship with the EU after Brexit.

"Having reviewed what has been agreed, it is clear that the Johnson deal is a far worse deal than Theresa May's deal. It paves the way for a decade of deregulation. It gives Johnson licence to slash workers' rights, environmental standards and consumer protections."

He added: " Labour will not support a flawed Brexit deal that harms jobs, rights and living standards. This deal will unquestionably do that.

"Labour cannot support this deal. If Boris Johnson has confidence in his deal, he should put it back to the people in a public vote against remain - and that is an argument we will be making on Saturday."

(Image: REUTERS)

Mr Johnson struck the last minute Brexit deal just three hours before 27 EU leaders met to decide if it should pass.

The PM jetted to Brussels early yesterday morning announcing a breakthrough following days of missed deadlines, chaos and counter-claim.

The Prime Minister finally agreed a deal after speaking to EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker by phone and chatting to a handful of Cabinet ministers.

Mr Johnson said: “It’s a reasonable, fair outcome and reflects the large amount of work that’s been undertaken by both sides.

“For us in the UK it means that we can deliver a real Brexit that achieves our objectives and it means the UK leaves whole and entire on October 31.”

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Jean-Claude Juncker added he was happy about the deal - even if sad about Brexit. He said: “We have a deal and this deal means that there is no need for any kind of prolongation.

“This is a fair a balanced agreement. It provides certainty where Brexit creates uncertainty.”

EU leaders unanimously signed off the deal at a political level rather than a full legally binding one as they need more time to trawl through the 500-page text.

The 64-page draft would keep a transition period continuing EU rules and payments to December 2020.

It scraps the hated Irish backstop with one UK official describing it as “finito”.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

The final draft deal today put forward a more complex system involving special rules on customs.

Labour slammed the plans - with shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer issuing stark warnings about the political declaration for the future relationship with the EU.

“It paves the way for a decade of deregulation. It gives Johnson licence to slash workers’ rights, environmental standards and consumer protections,” he said.

Jeremy Corbyn vowed to try and block the “sell-out” deal in the Commons on Saturday, warning it “won’t bring the country together”

The Labour leader said: “From what we know, it seems the Prime Minister has negotiated an even worse deal than Theresa May ’s, which was overwhelmingly rejected.

(Image: REUTERS)

“These proposals risk triggering a race to the bottom on rights and protections - putting food safety at risk, cutting environmental standards and workers’ rights, and opening up our NHS to a takeover by US private corporations.”

But the government insist they remained committed to upholding standards.

A senior official insisted the changes “don’t mark a step up or step down rather they represent a step to the side”.

He said they are based on a typical EU free trade arrangement such as with Canada or Japan.

“These proposals risk triggering a race to the bottom on rights and protections - putting food safety at risk, cutting environmental standards and workers’ rights, and opening up our NHS to a takeover by US private corporations.”

It comes together with a statement that sides will uphold high standards on environment, climate, workers’ rights and other rules.

A senior official insisted the changes “don’t mark a step up or step down rather they represent a step to the side”.

He said they are based on a typical EU free trade arrangement such as with Canada or Japan.

Trades Union Congress general secretary Frances O’Grady also cast doubt on the the strength of the protections.

She said: “This deal would be a disaster for working people.

“It would hammer the economy, cost jobs and sell workers’ rights down the river.

“Boris Johnson has negotiated an even worse deal than Theresa May. All MPs should vote against it.”

Boris Johnson insisted the UK would keep those protections: “It contains important provisions and commitments that this country gladly makes about our determination to maintain the highest possible standards both with the environment and with social protection.”

But the government remain optimistic to get wavering Labour MPs onboard with a senior source telling the Mirror there was “discreet outreach”.
description: The Prime Minister's deal has been monstered by Labour - here's how he finally got EU leaders to agree to it
